text: When a project I'm leading hits an unexpected obstacle, I find myself energized by the challenge of finding a new path forward.
In the last month, I've changed my approach to something after realizing my original plan wasn't working.
Once I've decided on a way of doing things, I stick with it even when people suggest alternatives.
When I fail at something, I actively study what went wrong so I can extract a specific lesson from it.
I feel uncomfortable when the rules or expectations at work shift without warning.
In the last month, I've sought out feedback that challenged how I see my own strengths.
When I'm learning a new skill, I push through the frustrating early stage where I'm bad at it rather than retreating to what I already know.
I find it hard to let go of a method I've personally developed, even when data shows a better option exists.
I always embrace change immediately, without any period of adjustment or discomfort.
If the core skill that built my career became obsolete tomorrow, I'd feel like I'd lost a part of who I am.
When someone on my team does things differently than I would, I let their approach stand as long as the outcome is solid.
I regularly read, watch, or listen to material outside my field specifically to expose myself to unfamiliar ideas.
I tend to consume information mostly within my own industry or area of expertise.
When I walk into a room where the social dynamics are unfamiliar, I adjust my communication style to fit the context.
I'd rather update a long-term plan based on new information than defend the original version.
When I receive critical feedback, my first instinct is to explain why I did what I did.
In the last month, I've deliberately practiced something I'm not naturally good at.
When I'm working with someone whose thinking style is very different from mine, I find ways to bridge the gap rather than defaulting to my preference.
I get frustrated when priorities shift mid-project and I have to rework something I already finished.
I define myself more by my ability to figure things out than by any single skill I currently have.
When I notice an early sign that my current approach isn't working, I course-correct quickly rather than waiting for definitive proof.
I've asked someone younger or less experienced than me to teach me something in the past three months.
When my team faces ambiguity, I feel a strong pull to create structure and clarity before moving forward.
When something I built gets scrapped, I can let go of it without taking it personally.
There are parts of how I work that I consider non-negotiable, regardless of what the situation calls for.
You've spent three weeks building a detailed project plan. On the day you're about to present it, leadership announces a major strategic pivot that makes half your plan irrelevant. You:

options.text: Immediately identify which parts of your plan still apply and start rebuilding around the new direction before the end of the day.
Present the original plan anyway, highlighting the parts that still work, and ask for a week to revise the rest.
Push back on the pivot, arguing that the original strategy was sound and the new direction hasn't been fully thought through.
Scrap the entire plan and start fresh, treating the old work as a sunk cost.

text: A new technology tool is rolled out across your organization. You've heard mixed reviews. Your current workflow is efficient and you're one of the top performers using the old system. You:

options.text: Volunteer to be an early adopter and commit to learning the new tool thoroughly, even though it will slow you down for weeks.
Wait until the tool is mandatory, then learn only what you need to maintain your current output.
Run both systems in parallel for a month to compare results before fully committing to either.
Advocate for keeping the old system, presenting data on your current performance as evidence it's still superior.

text: You're managing a team that just went through its third reorganization in eighteen months. Morale is low. People are saying, 'Here we go again.' You:

options.text: Acknowledge the fatigue openly, then help your team find one or two things they can control within the new structure and focus there.
Frame the reorganization as an opportunity and encourage the team to see the upside of the new structure.
Escalate to leadership that the constant changes are damaging performance and request a period of stability.
Keep your head down, implement the changes quietly, and focus on protecting your team from further disruption.

text: You've been the go-to expert on a specific process for five years. A junior colleague proposes a fundamentally different approach that, on the surface, looks promising but would make your expertise less relevant. You:

options.text: Genuinely evaluate the proposal on its merits, and if it's better, champion it publicly even though it diminishes your unique value.
Mentor the junior colleague to refine their idea, positioning yourself as the person who helped develop the innovation.
Point out the risks and edge cases their approach doesn't account for, drawing on your five years of experience.
Suggest a pilot test on a small project before committing to a full change.

text: You just moved from a large corporation to a scrappy startup. There's no playbook, no established processes, and people wear multiple hats. In your first week, you:

options.text: Jump in and start figuring things out through trial and error, asking questions as you go.
Spend the first two weeks observing how things work before taking action, to avoid making assumptions.
Start building the processes and documentation that are missing, drawing on your corporate experience.
Identify the one or two people who seem to know how things really work and shadow them closely.

text: Your industry is being disrupted by AI and automation. Tasks that used to take your team a week now take a day. Some of your team members are anxious about their relevance. You:

options.text: Proactively upskill yourself and your team on the new tools, redefining roles around what humans do better than machines.
Focus on the parts of your work that can't be automated and double down there.
Resist the changes and make the case that the human touch in your work can't be replicated by technology.
Wait to see how the industry settles before making any major changes to how your team operates.

text: You're in a meeting and realize you've been operating on an incorrect assumption for weeks. Correcting it now will mean admitting a mistake in front of peers and reworking a deliverable. You:

options.text: Speak up immediately, name the mistake, and propose a corrected path forward in the same conversation.
Quietly adjust your approach after the meeting and present the corrected version without drawing attention to the error.
Finish the meeting, then tell your manager privately before announcing the correction more broadly.
See if the assumption actually matters to the final outcome before deciding whether it's worth correcting.

text: You're leading a project using a methodology you've successfully used many times before. Halfway through, a team member presents evidence that a completely different methodology would yield better results for this specific project. You:

options.text: Pause the project, assess the evidence honestly, and switch methodologies if the case is strong enough.
Incorporate elements of the new methodology while keeping the overall structure of your proven approach.
Acknowledge the input but continue with your methodology, noting that consistency matters more than optimization.
Ask the team member to build a detailed comparison before making any changes, to avoid disrupting momentum.

text: You've been promoted to lead a department you have no background in. You're surrounded by people who know far more about the work than you do. In your first month, you:

options.text: Tell your team openly that you're here to learn from them, ask each person what they'd change if they could, and focus on removing obstacles.
Study the department's metrics, processes, and history intensively before making any changes or public statements.
Bring in frameworks and practices from your previous department that you know work, adapting them to the new context.
Identify the strongest performer on the team and rely heavily on them as your guide while you get up to speed.

text: A client abruptly changes the scope of a project two days before the deadline. The new scope is doable but requires a completely different approach than what you've built. You:

options.text: Accept the change, rally the team, and rebuild from scratch using the tightest possible timeline.
Negotiate with the client to push the deadline by a week so you can deliver the new scope properly.
Deliver the original scope on time and propose the new scope as a follow-up phase.
Find a creative hybrid that addresses the client's new priorities while preserving as much of your existing work as possible.

text: You discover that a belief you've held about effective leadership for years is contradicted by strong evidence. Specifically, a practice you've been coaching others on turns out to be counterproductive. You:

options.text: Go back to the people you've coached, share what you've learned, and help them unlearn the practice alongside you.
Quietly stop using the practice yourself and adopt the evidence-based approach going forward, without making a big deal of it.
Dig deeper into the evidence before changing anything, since your direct experience tells a different story.
Acknowledge the evidence but note that what works depends on context, and your approach may still be valid in certain situations.

text: You're running a team meeting and someone raises a concern that completely contradicts the direction you just proposed. The room goes quiet. You:

options.text: Thank them for the pushback, explore their concern seriously in front of the group, and adjust your proposal if warranted.
Acknowledge the concern, say you'll think about it, and move on to keep the meeting on track.
Address the concern point by point, explaining why your direction accounts for it.
Open it up to the room for discussion, stepping back from your position to let the team weigh in.

text: You've been asked to take on a role that requires skills you don't currently have. You'll be visibly learning on the job, and mistakes will be public. You:

options.text: Accept the role, tell stakeholders upfront about your learning curve, and set milestones to track your progress transparently.
Accept the role and quietly study everything you can before your start date so the learning is less visible.
Decline and recommend someone with the right existing skill set, knowing it's better for the organization.
Accept the role but negotiate for a mentor or co-lead who has the skills you lack.

text: Your team has been doing something the same way for three years. It works fine, but you suspect it could be significantly better. There's no pressure to change. You:

options.text: Run an experiment on a small scale to test whether a new approach delivers measurably better results.
Leave it alone. If it's working, the risk of change outweighs the potential upside.
Bring the idea to the team and see if anyone else has been thinking about improvements.
Research what other organizations are doing in the same area and benchmark your approach.

text: You receive a performance review that gives you high marks on results but low marks on collaboration. You've always believed your direct, efficient style was a strength. You:

options.text: Ask three trusted colleagues for specific examples of how your style has affected them, and commit to experimenting with a different approach.
Accept the feedback but remind yourself that results speak louder, and continue focusing on what you're best at.
Adjust your behavior in visible ways during meetings and projects over the next quarter to address the perception.
Have a candid conversation with your manager about whether collaboration is being weighted appropriately relative to outcomes.

text: You've recently failed at a high-visibility initiative. It was your idea, your plan, and your execution. The failure is unambiguous. In the week after, you:

options.text: Write a detailed post-mortem, share it with stakeholders, and identify exactly what you'd do differently.
Take time to process the failure privately before engaging with others about what went wrong.
Immediately start a new initiative to demonstrate that you can bounce back and deliver.
Analyze external factors that contributed to the failure to develop a more complete picture of what happened.

text: You're working with a team from a different culture where the communication norms are very different from yours. Decisions happen slower, feedback is indirect, and hierarchy matters more than you're used to. You:

options.text: Study the cultural norms, adapt your communication style, and treat it as an opportunity to expand how you operate.
Meet them halfway by adjusting some of your habits while being transparent about your natural style.
Maintain your usual style but be patient and respectful, trusting that good work will speak across cultural differences.
Appoint a cultural liaison from the other team to help translate between communication styles.

text: Your proven method just stopped working. Your first thought:

options.text: Good. I was getting bored of it anyway. Time to find something better.
I need to figure out why it stopped working before I abandon something that's served me well.

text: A new hire suggests completely rethinking your core process. You feel:

options.text: Curious. Fresh eyes often see what we've become blind to.
Skeptical. They don't yet understand why things are done this way.

text: You realize you've been wrong about something for years. Your reaction:

options.text: Relief, almost. Now I can stop building on a faulty foundation.
A sinking feeling. All that effort based on the wrong assumption.

text: The industry you've built your career in is being completely transformed. Honestly, your gut says:

options.text: I'll ride this wave. I've reinvented myself before and I'll do it again.
I need to protect what I've built. Deep expertise still matters, even when everything is shifting.

text: You're dropped into a situation where nothing you know applies. The feeling that hits you first:

options.text: A quiet thrill. This is where real growth happens.
Anxiety. I need to find something familiar to anchor to before I can move forward.

text: Someone gives you feedback that completely contradicts your self-image. You're most likely to:

options.text: Sit with it seriously. If multiple people see this, maybe my self-image needs updating.
Consider the source. Not everyone sees the full picture of who I am and why I operate the way I do.

text: Your team's direction changed three times this quarter. When someone asks how you're handling it, the honest answer is:

options.text: I've learned to hold plans loosely. I focus on what's in front of me and adjust as it shifts.
It's exhausting. I need stability to do my best work, and this constant shifting is burning me out.

text: If you had to choose between these two career paths for the next five years:

options.text: A role that changes every six months -- new problems, new teams, new skills required each time.
A role that deepens over time -- same domain, increasing mastery, growing reputation as the expert.

text: The last time you were completely out of your depth, you noticed yourself:

options.text: Asking more questions than usual and paying close attention to people who knew things I didn't.
Drawing on principles from past experiences to create a framework I could operate from.

text: When you think about who you are as a leader, the thing that feels most true:

options.text: I'm someone who evolves. The leader I am today is different from who I was two years ago, and I expect that to keep changing.
I'm someone with a clear identity. People know what they're getting with me, and that consistency is what makes me trustworthy.
